children.comments:
Composes `Alt Maybe` with `Alt f`.
This does not seem likely to be particularly useful, but then again, what does?

If you just want the first nonempty `MaybeEmpty f a`, `unwrap` it to `Maybe (f a)`.
children.title: maybeEmptyAlt

children.comments:
`empty = none`. Does not use `Plus f` if it exists--and given that
this is all about wrapping guaranteed non-empty containers, it probably doesn't.
children.title: maybeEmptyPlus

declarations.comments:
Lift an `Unfoldable1` into an `Unfoldable` by wrapping it in `Maybe`,
such that an empty sequence gives `Nothing` and a nonempty sequence gives
a nonempty `Unfoldable1` in `Just`.
declarations.title: MaybeEmpty

declarations.comments:
Convenience wrapper for `maybe` on the inner `Maybe`. Can save an
`import Data.Newtype (un)` if this is all you need from Data.Unfoldable.MaybeEmpty.
declarations.title: maybeEmpty

declarations.comments:
Creates an `f` containing a single `Nothing` if empty.

Although Data.Unfoldable calls them "unfoldable functors", `Functor` isn't actually
a superclass of `Unfoldable1`. On the off chance that you for some reason do in fact
have an `Unfoldable1` type which is not a `Functor` but also want to use this,
consider `emptyIfNone` from `Data.Unfoldable.Trivial` instead.
declarations.title: distributeMaybes

declarations.comments: Creates an `f` containing `Nothing` if empty, using `pure` instead of `singleton`.
declarations.title: distributeMaybesA

declarations.comments: Unwraps and converts the inner `Maybe` into an alternative `Alternative`. *(ba dum tss)*
declarations.title: toAlternative

modules.comments:
This "module" provides various adapters and other such utilities
for `Unfoldable1` and `Unfoldable`.

declarations.comments:
Returns the first element, if present.

Not particularly useful, because this is just the `Unfoldable`
instance for `Maybe`. Included by analogy with `head1`.
declarations.title: head

declarations.comments: Removes the first element, if present.
declarations.title: tail

declarations.comments: Returns the last element, if present.
declarations.title: last

declarations.comments: Removes the last element, if present.
declarations.title: init

declarations.comments: Keep only a number of elements from the start.
declarations.title: take

declarations.comments:
Prepend an element.

Do not use this to create a data structure. Please use Data.List.Lazy instead.
declarations.title: cons

declarations.comments:
Append an element.

Do not use this to create a data structure. Please use Data.List.Lazy instead.
declarations.title: snoc

declarations.comments:
Returns the first element and a new `Unfoldable` generating the remaining elements,
or `Nothing` if there are no elements.
declarations.title: uncons

declarations.comments:
Get the element at the specified 0-index, or `Nothing` if the index is out-of-bounds.

Time complexity: `O(n)` in the index (calls to the generating function).
declarations.title: index

declarations.comments: Drop a number of elements from the start.
declarations.title: drop

declarations.comments:
`foldl` specialized to `Trivial`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldl

declarations.comments:
`foldr` specialized to `Trivial`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldr

declarations.comments:
`foldMap` specialized to `Trivial`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldMap

declarations.comments:
`fold` specialized to `Trivial`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refold

declarations.comments:
Lift the elements of an `Unfoldable` into an `Alternative` (such as `Maybe`),
filling in a single `empty` if there are no elements.

If you more generally want to augment an `Unfoldable1` with emptiness,
you almost certainly should use `MaybeEmpty` instead.
declarations.title: emptyIfNone

modules.name: Data.Unfoldable.Trivial

declarations.comments:
Provides a default implementation of `unfoldr1` using `unfoldr` to satisfy
the superclass bound on `Unfoldable`.
declarations.title: unfoldr1Default

declarations.comments:
Function application specialized to a `Trivial` argument,
at the same precedence as `($)`.

Inspired by the Rust syntax of the same name, often used in the
analogous context of collecting from an iterator.
declarations.title: turbofish

declarations.comments: Specializes its argument to `Trivial`.
declarations.title: trivial

children.comments: Wraps both arguments to `unfoldr1` in an `Unfoldr1Call`.
children.title: trivial1Unfoldable1

children.comments:
The *raison d'être* for `Trivial1`.
Allows folding polymorphic `Unfoldable1`s as they generate
with no explicit starting value. In particular, `foldMap1`
needs map only into a `Semigroup` rather than a `Monoid`.

`foldr1` uses a default implementation and may be inefficient.
children.title: trivial1Foldable1

declarations.comments:
A type wrapping `unfoldr1` calls, existentially quantified over the seed type
so that it can be ignored in the type constructor. Its `Unfoldable1` instance
means that it can directly be constructed by calling `unfoldr1`.
declarations.title: Trivial1

declarations.comments:
Unfold an infinite `Unfoldable1`.
Analogous to `unfold1` and `unfold`, but with no way to signal termination;
`unfoldInf f b` consists of `fst $ f b` appended to `unfoldInf f $ snd $ f b`.

This should only be used to produce either lazy types (like `Trivial`) or
types with truncating `Unfoldable1` instances (like `Maybe`).
declarations.title: unfoldrInf

declarations.comments: Returns the first element, and an `Unfoldable` of the remaining elements.
declarations.title: uncons1

declarations.comments:
Function application specialized to a `Trivial1` argument,
at the same precedence as `($)`.

Inspired by the Rust syntax of the same name, often used in the
analogous context of collecting from an iterator.
declarations.title: turbofish1

declarations.comments: Specializes its argument to `Trivial1`.
declarations.title: trivial1

declarations.comments: Keep only a strictly positive number of elements from the start.
declarations.title: take1

declarations.comments:
`foldr1` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldr1

declarations.comments:
`foldl1` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldl1

declarations.comments:
`foldMap` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish1`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldMap1

declarations.comments:
`fold` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish1`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refold1

declarations.comments: Returns the last element.
declarations.title: last1

declarations.comments:
Create an infinite `Unfoldable1` by repeated application of a function to a seed value. 
Analogous to `iterateN`, but with no iteration limit.

This should only be used to produce either lazy types (like `Trivial`) or
types with truncating `Unfoldable1` instances (like `Maybe`).
declarations.title: iterate

declarations.comments:
Get the element at the specified *modular* 0-index, i.e. the element
at that 0-index in the elements infinitely extended left and right.

Will loop infinitely if given an infinite `Unfoldable1` and a negative index.
Will not loop infinitely if given an infinite `Unfoldable1` and a nonnegative index;
computes the length for itself as it iterates. Iterates twice when resolving an out of
bounds index; does not store any intermediate results. In general, this function is
not supposed to be *used for modular indexing*, because modular indexing just happens
to be a simple and sensible way to guarantee an output, and there's no point in this
existing without a guaranteed output (just use `index`).
If you want modular indexing for the mod, please use an actual container.
declarations.title: index1

declarations.comments: Returns the first element.
declarations.title: head1

declarations.comments:
Map each element of a `BoundedEnum` into a semigroup,
and combine the results through `refold1`.
declarations.title: foldEnum

modules.comments:
This module provides the `Trivial` type as an existentially quantified
dumb wrapper around `unfold`, which can be inspected and manipulated
to implement various typeclasses and the utilities in Data.Unfoldable.Trivial.

This module also contains the implementations of utilities which rely on directly
inspecting `Trivial` values and are re-exported by Data.Unfoldable.Trivial.
Use this module directly only if you intend to directly inspect `Trivial` values yourself.

children.comments: Wraps both arguments to `unfoldr` in an `UnfoldrCall`.
children.title: trivialUnfoldable

children.comments:
The *raison d'être* for `Trivial`.
Allows folding polymorphic `Unfoldable`s as they generate.

`foldr` uses a default implementation and may be inefficient.
Note also that this enables the use of `sequence_`
despite the lack of a `Traversable` instance, which is not provided because
it would require forcing and accumulating every value, at which point
any would-be user is better off with an actual container.
children.title: trivialFoldable

declarations.comments:
A type wrapping `unfoldr` calls, existentially quantified over the seed type
so that it can be ignored in the type constructor. Its `Unfoldable` instance
means that it can directly be constructed by calling `unfoldr`.
declarations.title: Trivial

declarations.comments: Alias for the generator function passed to `unfoldr`.
declarations.title: Generator

declarations.comments: Specializes its argument to `Trivial`.
declarations.title: trivial

declarations.comments:
Convenience function for inspecting `Trivial` values.
Calls the function argument on the contents of the inner `Exists`.
declarations.title: untrivial

declarations.comments:
Function application specialized to a `Trivial` argument,
at the same precedence as `($)`.

Inspired by the Rust syntax of the same name, often used in the
analogous context of collecting from an iterator.
declarations.title: turbofish

declarations.comments:
Provides a default implementation of `unfoldr1` using `unfoldr` to satisfy
the superclass bound on `Unfoldable`.
declarations.title: unfoldr1Default

declarations.comments:
Converts to any other `Unfoldable`.
Can also be seen as evaluating the inner `UnfoldrCall`.

This is only useful in implementing utility functions.
In all other cases, simply use the desired type directly.
declarations.title: runTrivial

modules.name: Data.Unfoldable.Trivial.Internal

modules.comments:
This module provides various adapters and other such utilities
for `Unfoldable1`.

declarations.comments:
`foldl1` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldl1

declarations.comments:
`foldr1` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldr1

declarations.comments:
`foldMap` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish1`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refoldMap1

declarations.comments:
`fold` specialized to `Trivial1`. "Re-fold" a polymorphic `Unfoldable1`.
Usually cleaner and more convenient than `turbofish1`, when applicable.
declarations.title: refold1

declarations.comments:
Map each element of a `BoundedEnum` into a semigroup,
and combine the results through `refold1`.
declarations.title: foldEnum

declarations.comments:
Unfold an infinite `Unfoldable1`.
Analogous to `unfold1` and `unfold`, but with no way to signal termination;
`unfoldInf f b` consists of `fst $ f b` appended to `unfoldInf f $ snd $ f b`.

This should only be used to produce either lazy types (like `Trivial`) or
types with truncating `Unfoldable1` instances (like `Maybe`).
declarations.title: unfoldrInf

declarations.comments:
Create an infinite `Unfoldable1` by repeated application of a function to a seed value. 
Analogous to `iterateN`, but with no iteration limit.

This should only be used to produce either lazy types (like `Trivial`) or
types with truncating `Unfoldable1` instances (like `Maybe`).
declarations.title: iterate

declarations.comments: Returns the first element.
declarations.title: head1

declarations.comments: Returns the last element.
declarations.title: last1

declarations.comments: Keep only a strictly positive number of elements from the start.
declarations.title: take1

declarations.comments:
Get the element at the specified *modular* 0-index, i.e. the element
at that 0-index in the elements infinitely extended left and right.

Will loop infinitely if given an infinite `Unfoldable1` and a negative index.
Will not loop infinitely if given an infinite `Unfoldable1` and a nonnegative index;
computes the length for itself as it iterates. Iterates twice when resolving an out of
bounds index; does not store any intermediate results. In general, this function is
not supposed to be *used for modular indexing*, because modular indexing just happens
to be a simple and sensible way to guarantee an output, and there's no point in this
existing without a guaranteed output (just use `index`).
If you want modular indexing for the mod, please use an actual container.
declarations.title: index1

`foldr1` uses a default implementation and may be inefficient.

at the same precedence as `($)`.

packageMeta.name: purescript-trivial-unfold
